number of helpful: 147 of 152 people (97%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Welcome back to Roller Coaster Tycoon. If you remember anything about the first game, then you'll know everything about this version. Right off the bat, the only big difference is larger parks to put your fiendish death coasters into. Other than that, there are minor difference here and there such as now your patrons will take photos of cool stuff like coasters. They can now seek out a first aide station if they feel very sick and if they run out of cash, there's always an automatic teller machine! You'll also find a coaster designer out of game. Other than that, the difficulty seems to have gotten ramped up from the previous game. There are no easy victories here, but its not about the victory, since all 58 scenarios are unlocked from the start. Because this is Triple Thrill Pack, its not just RCT2, but its got all three expansion packs in one dirt cheap price.For anyone that doesn't know, Roller Coaster Tycoon 1 and 2 are theme park management games that let you build roller coasters and plop down attractions in an isometric view. What really makes RCT stand out more than any other management game is the fact that you indeed design your own roller coasters! Its fun and easy, first select the type of attraction, then put down a platform and you can make it as long or short as you want. Then in most cases make a lift hill, then some turns, drops, ups and downs, spirals, loops, a helix, a cobra roll and so on. Every type of coaster has different trains, tracks, and specifics.After you're done with your coaster, make an entrance and an exit. Don't forget a line cue to your entrance. This is for everyone waiting in line. A long line cue means boredom sets in and you might need to hire a mascot to entertain them as they wait. Having beautiful decorations also helps keep people entertained. There are many different themes to enable. Even more with the three expansion packs! Perhaps too many, but having so much lets you create something you want.Rides get broken down into three ratings. Excitement, intensity and nausea. To boost excitement, add more decorations, set it next to another ride if not through another ride. Every visitor has their own preference. some can tolerate high nausea, others want low intensity and so on. The tighter the turns, the higher the nausea rating. When someone comes out of your ride they can be sick. So from there have benches waiting for them to rest and regain their composure otherwise they'll heave on the ground and then you'll need handymen tot clean it up.You can hire an array of staff, handymen, mechanics, entertainers and security. Then assign them each to have a patrol. Its a nice system to cover a lot of ground. Handymen and other staff have check boxes to determine what you want them to do, stuff like water gardens, clear out trash and mow lawns. Its all your choice.If you don't want to build coasters, there are pre-built designs that you can plop down, but you can reap the benefits by making your own custom coaster. You can make it dip down into the ground for a tunnel, hang over water and contour it to the hills and valleys of your land to save money.There's even a new feature in RCT2 that will let you design your own coaster without needing to build it right there on the fly in a theme park. This is a money saving feature, because building one in your theme park still costs you money and you might run out. The only problem with using the design editor is that if you need to use the tool, you'll need to save your game, drop out of it, go back into the menu, select the design tool, open it up, make a coaster, save it, get out of the editor, jump back into your save game and then plop down your custom coaster as a pre-built. Some people just want to design coasters, they don't want all the frills of managing an entire park and the coaster designer lets  you do that. RCT2 cares about those people.I mentioned the 58 scenarios, each one puts you into a pre-existing area, such as a castle, an airfield, and yes even the moon itself. It definitely adds a lot of flair and character that the original game lacked without expansion packs. While these environments are big, detailed and beautiful on their own, I feel like its too much to just start out in. You've got dozens of paths going everywhere when all you need to start is a quarter of a gigantic park. So then to keep from having your visitors walk all over the place, you'll put down barricades over your paths that don't let them cross.Each one of these scenarios has different conditions to win. Everything from get X amount of dollars in Y amount of years to having X amount of patrons in your park by year Y. There's a lot of variety and between the conditions and the environments, it keeps the game interesting and fresh from park to park. It gives me a reason to keep playing, because one year in the game is an hour in real life. These scenarios often last 3+ years, making for what could be a 175 hour game and that's assuming you stop playing a scenario when you complete it! You can keep going on and on to your heart's content.The longer you go, the more your rides will break down. A new ride draws more people while an old ride, just feels stale and familiar. That's why you can save the ride, bulldoze it for some money and rebuild it again at full price! Its not just fictional parks in Africa or medieval times, there's a section of real life parks from the late 90s. Six real life parks including Magic Mountain and others owned by Six Flags.Outside of roller coasters, log rides and anything else with a track, there are lesser rides that you can just plop down and make an entrance and an exit to. You can customize the entrances with themes and customize the paths, ground height, water, plants and so on. It all costs a price of course, but you can make exactly what you want to. Speaking of that, if you want to turn your roller coasters into death traps go for it! Its one of the fun things about the game. Make a power launch roller coaster shoot people off the rails sending them to their demise! Don't expect anyone to ever ride the coaster ever again, even after you fix it! Cowards.Your guests will need to eat, drink and go to the bathroom, so don't forget to place vendors in strategic locations. They'll need places to sit and garbage cans too. There is a wide array of shops too, sunglasses, T-shirts, caps and balloons to sell. Place them where people are happiest and they'll spend for sure.You'll get to manage the park's finances, but you won't get lost or overwhelmed. Its all pretty easy. You can quickly take out a cheap loan from the bank if you need money. You can spend money on advertising for the park, specific rides or other such things and they have a great impact on your visitors. To unlock new attractions, you'll need to put money into research. The more money per month, the quicker rides will be enabled in the scenario.With everything said, RCT2 like its predecessor is a relaxing time sink that you can enjoy for decades like I did. I was still playing RCT2 on CD-ROM before it came to Steam! There's something here for management fans, coaster buffs and creation enthusiasts. While I feel like the vanilla version of RCT2 didn't have that many parks for the original price tag, the three included expansion packs make it a much better game.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This game. Oh man, this game. I got my first disk copy out of a box of Cheerios, and I played the absolute hell out of it. I easily poured about three thousand hours into that disk, and I loved every second of it. By the end of it I had well over 200 save files, some of which were actual serious parks and the rest simple sandbox parks where I had no objective and just ♥♥♥♥ed around with the patrons.Then, the unthinkable happened. A virus destroyed the family computer, and when we got a new one, I found that the disk refused to install on it.Fast forward ten or so years later. I was browsing steam out of boredom when I stumbled across Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 again, bundled together with its two expansion packs for a humble price of $11 CAN. Childhood memories came rushing back in a blur and I nearly fell off my bed in sheer excitement. A week later I got my hands on a copy of the game (Thank you, Jordy!!) and I was soon on my way to a serious nostalgia trip.The Pros!It is a legitimate challenge while still being fun! The game, yes, does get quite frustrating at times but there is never any disappointment in starting over. It just leaves you with a feeling of knowing you can do better in your next try. Plus there is nothing more satisfying than building a successful park and watching the money pour in.Truly a game for all ages. Considering how far I managed to get as a kid, and how I still love it as an adult years later shows how easy it is to grasp and master by younger audiences, while still being challenging and entertaining enough to hold the attention spans of older gamers. It is because RCT2 can be as easy or as difficult as you want it to be, solely with the help of;The scenario editor. It is a separate game mode accessed through the main menu screen, and it offers up a near endless stream of custom parks long after you have beaten the rest of the ones included in the game. You can customize things such as the guests' preference to less or more intense rides, the rules on the park property itself (IE; ride height and land modifying restrictions), hell, even the climate of the area itself. There is so much there that can be tweaked to your liking, so you are left with a park that is catered to your own unique sense of challenge.Building Roller Coasters is awesome. There is a huge selection of ride types to work with, giving a lot of opportunity for creativity. Building the rides is strangely relaxing, too.Honourable Mentions:- Graphics and animations are awesome for a game from 2002- UI is simple and easy to navigate- Very minimal bugs and glitchesThe Cons!Patron and Staff AI is simple, and not in a good way. It is quite stupid and can get frustrating at times. (Guests don't know how to use First Aid centres, or how to find the bathrooms/food stalls. They're like tiny, ant sized cattle, all aimlessly wandering around in circles.)Game has some compatibility issues. Particularly with newer computers (Win 7 and on), but all of those problems can be easily fixed with these guides.Game can get a little boring sometimes. especially during periods where you have no money to work with, and end up waiting for funds from rides and shops to stock you up again. It's a problem that veterans of the Sim City games will be familiar with. If you have a consistent stream of money coming in from those sources however, it won't be much of a problem.The Final Verdict!Despite its flaws, Rollercoaster Tycoon 2 is a solid theme park simulator that has aged well. And for under fifteen dollars, you really can't go wrong. I recommend it wholeheartedly with a 9/10.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												It's pretty hard not to do a joke review about this game with all of the top-tier memes it gives you.However, this is a game I hold dearly. It has a place in my heart no other game can fill, and it will always be the first computer game I ever had that gave me something to show off to friends with.You see, if you got this game from a cereal box (like most of us did), you are part of the best generation to experience PC gaming.Or, who knows. Maybe you played the crap out of text-based adventures back in the day and just happened to love sugary cereal at the tender age of adulthood.It truly was a good time to get into the idea of gaming on your computer. Not because legendary, classic titles came in cereal boxes, but because everyone of the "common genres" of game weren't set in stone yet and plenty of new companies were making PC games that were always probing an aspect of the video game that hasn't been looked into before. Nowadays the market of new games can be separated into "niche indie titles", "AAA games with PC ports" and the rare "well-rounded good game". Back then... you had the Tycoon series.Ladies and gentlemen, the Tycoon series of games was probably what saved me from adolescent boredom and actually gave me something fun to do on Windows 98.Bored after school? Boot up "Extreme Heights" and build another coaster that manages to do 10 loops in a row.You could basically build whatever park you wanted and force dumb, oblivious NPCs to eat up whatever crap you make. The system was intricate. It was always giving you feedback for how reasonable your setup is, as well as fine-tuning over even the most menial tasks.The slow nature of the game gave the players a lot of choice and challenge. Do you spend all of your money at once for something that can either make or break the park, or build a bunch of safe, small rides that will only gradually build me money?It feels a little weird writing this review because of the fact that I never really stopped with RollerCoaster Tycoon games. It's a game I will always respect and my one hope is that it is never lost and forgotten.The nostalgia value in this game is equivalent to Sock 'Em Boppers and Lincoln Logs.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 is likely my favorite game of all time.I've put much more than 500 hours into it spanning my entire life and continued to play it as a non-steam game whilest it was not available on Steam. When I saw that it was, my wallet got sad, because in just a few moments my money was gone.This is in my opinion THE best RollerCoaster video game in existance, and well for that matter in my opinion the best Tycoon game of any developer. Everything is made to a precise definity and managing your park is easy, but at the same time heavily difficult! The more you know about how to play this game, the more fun it becomes.There is no game out there like this one, and at first glance it might seem like a learning curve but it's actually quite straight forward, and I don't think anybody who could understand this game could play it and not enjoy it.Manage parks, build sweet rides, customize e.v.e.r.y.t.h.i.n.g to your desire and get creative with coaster designs! There is literally not much that this game does NOT have to offer in regards to a coaster park simulator, and even more is here with the thrills from the Triple Thrill Pack.Endless entertainment, thousands of ways to keep you entertained, and it's publicity proves that this game has a great reputation. I give it a 10/10, and it's not easy to get that from me. Let's just hope it stays that way for the upcoming RollerCoaster Tycoon 4!...and enough of this 4mobile bull****.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Part of my childhood is now in my Steam Library.Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 is a fun addictive sim game, where the goal is to create a park and achieve a specific objective. Whether it be get so many people to your park, have a high park rating by year 3, etc. You can achieve this by creating rides, adding decorations, hiring staff members to keep the park in shape, adding food stands, the list goes on and on. While Roller Coaster Tycoon 1 was the original, this game feels like it takes it one step further. Cleaning up the UI, adding new decorations, fixing some AI and adding completely new rides. Now you may be thinking, "why by this version when I can buy RCT3 which is in 3d?" Thats where I think they went wrong by making the game 3d. It doesnt have the charm that this game has. I did have a problem where the game was crashing on me whenever I saved or loaded game. I managed to fix it by running the game in Windows XP (SP2) and admin. I'm running Win. 8.1, so this fix might not work for all of you.  All in all I recommend this game to people who like casual games, sim games, fun games (not really a category but the game is fun), heck even a hardcore gamer might like this (Im a hardcore gamer so hopefully you share this opinion) For a great value of $10 you can have hours, upon hours of entertainment, which includes everything RCT2 has to offer! I had the basic version of the game when I was a kid, so to see the new stuff they added that I never got to experience makes the game even more worth it. Overall I give this game a 8.5/10. Get this game, its completely worth it!

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Where I grew up, in rural eastern Ukraine, in the early 2000's, there was no internet, no smartphones, no kfc and NO FREE PORN! There was however intel pentium...and Roller Coaster Tycoon!!. I remember spending hours, meticulously building my park from scratch, earning milions on big rides and food, attracting 6k+ guests into my park...and then torturing them, by cutting off the escape routes, flooding paths and charging $15 for toilet. And it was magical, pure joy. Even now, with the graphics definitely looking tired, it will bring you hours of very simple fun, build a ride and see how much you can charge before guests say its enough. Or starve them, then build one burger bar, put a very steep price and watch money flooding in. Or even better, build a coaster that will eventually crash, then comfort all the mourners with free black balloons...and free rides on the coaster that just has crashed! Yes, this game was always my favourite, a safe haven where I could unleash all my sadistic fantasies! And after all these years, nothing has changed, I still love to see the message 'Robert D. has just drowned'.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
Rank: 8/10Recommendation(s): Don’t expect to play a classic on new systems.Major Theme: Old school means it doesn’t need any schooling.Bought at Price: $5.99 (Steam Sale)I might be one of the select few to have actually played this game with real CDs (yes CDs… Not DVDs). Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 were my go to games before I joined Steam.Maybe it’s the simplicity of the title, or the enjoyment of charging people to go to the bathroom. Whatever the case might be, if you have an older system you are likely to enjoy this title.If you happened to give into Microsoft marketing and upgraded to 8/8.1/10, you should seek OpenRCT2 in addition. RC2 is a game built in assembly (really, just look at the system requirements) it will almost be required for you to use OpenRCT2 to play this title.The game plays out of the box on Windows 7, but beware that it uses a lower color depth, and alt+tab users should not be alarmed by the change in color modes.Resolutions are also minimally supported, the max usable for 16:9 users being 720. Obviously, you aren’t playing this game for the “leading” graphics.All the other later games in the series personally don’t seem to add anything meaningful, so I’d advise you to just grab RC2 and leave it at that.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Rollercoaster Tycoon 2, a classical themepark building game which I grew up with. Best one out there for sure, since, what is there not to love?Create the park of your dreams, with loads of rides, theming and so forth. Create extreme rollercoasters and watch your guest ride it (and crash it, I mean, hey, thats fun time to time ;) ), create flat rides like a Merry-Go-Round (and eventually getting Controle Failure, freaking you out should it be the first time of you experiencing it as the music speeds up), create thrill rides (potentially crashing this as well), water rides, stalls and so forth in your park. Besides building (and just screwing around), you also need to take care of your guests needs; example of this is put enough toilets in your park, drink stalls, food stalls and so forth, while also hiring staff whom clean your paths, maintain the rides, entertain guests, and even get rid of vandals.Though, admittedly, the guest AI can be dumb at times. Make a double path, and your guests can get lost at times. Your path is close to the exit, but it doesnt connect to it, so they have to walk around? They'll get lost. Pathfinding of them isn't too well at times. But, let this not break the game for you!Besides the issue described above, there is much to do in this game. But BE WARNED. This game will suck up a lot of time, when you have fun. Time can fly, as you make your own parks, and do things you want.After all these years, it still holds up. So.. why are you still reading this? Shoo, throw money at your screen in a desperate attempt, buy it, and have fun drowning people- eh, I mean building rollercoasters!It's a definite 10/10.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												When I was looking for a flash drive in my desk, I happened upon a disk that I had nearly forgotten about. My old copy of Rollercoaster Tycoon 2 had survived through 3 different operating systems, 4 computers and much more, but I hadn’t used it since 2010. I popped it in my computer and started to install, but to my dismay the years had caught up with it and the installation had failed.It then occurred to me that Steam may have a copy, and indeed it does. I haven’t played this game for so long, but starting it up to hear the old theme brought me back immediately. While I do assume that most buyers here on steam are gamers looking for nostalgia, I would like to talk about the game for possible newcomers as well.While RCT 2 may not be too big of a change compared to the original, there is no doubt that there is much more for you to do. More rides, stalls, park options and more are available, along with plenty of rides inspired by Six Flag rides. Customization within the game can feel endless, building everything from log plumes to corkscrew rollercoasters, but you can always just take pre-built rides if you’re in a rush as well. While customization is the main idea of RCT 2, management is also important. If you want to build more, you’re going to need more mechanics to keep your rides running. If your rides are intense people will puke and that will mean more handymen. You have to juggle expenses with customer happiness to make sure you don’t go out of business, and make sure you hit the park’s goal in time too.This is not to say that the game is perfect—there are plenty of little glitches that are infuriating at times. There are two types of parks: those you pay to enter, and those that are free but are charged for individual rides. When playing a pay-to-enter, you set your admission. When your park has a lot of great rides you can charge more, but that doesn’t mean your guests know that. I’ve built huge, sprawling parks and charged admission at $80+, still winning “best value park” awards, but people only carrying $20, $40 or $68 may still come up to my gates, only to be denied entry. This means that all these potential guests (and revenue) just doesn’t come into my park.Along with this are little other bugs. Wide-screen is all but impossible without modification to the game, and guests can complain about “over-crowding” when there are too many people on one path, even get stuck on paths if there are too many people on it, creating an endless loop. The simple solution would be to have a double-wide path, but the AI continues on, ignoring the extra space and complaining the entire time. In the end this won’t do too much to hurt your score, but the fact remains that if you look at your guests aggregate thoughts, be prepared for things you can’t fix. Bugs aside, I still see RCT2 is a masterpiece. As I work now to perfect every park, it seems hard to believe this game is almost 12 years old. You can see it in its graphics and mechanics, but it still has plenty of charm. If you love Tycoon games, I definitely recommend this one. Between customization, management and plenty of other options, this game still has plenty of charm, for newcomers and veterans alike.

												Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 is one of the most amazing simulation games to date. The potential for creativity is unlimited in this game, where the world - or in this case, your theme park - is literally your playground. content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												This is the first game i have ever played.For me it was everything, and it actually still is.The simple yet so clear concept.The total freedom of choice.You can create your own landscape's, theme park, build unique rollercoasters, treat you customers as you like(even drowning them or performing acts of torture) You can build various attractions, from easy slow going attractions, to exciting attractions and even rollercoasters.Building attractions is not the only thing you need to focus on, your guests will also have needs that you need to satisfy.For instance, plop a few drink and food stalls so your customers can eat, but also plop some benches to sit on, and some garbage cans for your guests to leave their garbage. If not the garbage will be thrown on the ground and give your park a bad reputation.Attractions don't make the park, no. You'll also need to make it pretty. Plant some flowers in your park. Add decor and theme's. There are various theme's to choose from. For instance, candyland or the jungle theme. But it's not all as easy at it seems.You'll also need to hire staff. Staff such as mechanics to inspect attractions and fix them if they break down. But also security guards, to prevent your guests from breaking stuff in your park.This all costs money, money and money. You'll need guests to keep your park operational. You can do whatever you want, if you want to play with money, you play with money. If you don't want to play with money, you play with unlimited funds. Does that make it easy? Still, not. Your guests still rate your park on various aspects such as the beauty, safety, waiting queue's, the overall beauty of the park and lots more.This game is old, but certainly not bad.I favor this game over RollerCoaster Tycoon 3.

The shortcut should be on the desktop, double click the shortcut and it will launch the game (Thats what I did)

												This game is almost the defenition of a "perfect" game. Keep in mind I said almost, but that is beside the point. This game lets you create a theme park and watch as hundreds upon THOUSANDS of tiny little guests enter your park, buy your merchandise, and ride your crazy rides. This game is much more linear compared to its sequel (which is not a good game at all) which makes it a much better choice for amusement park management. The amount of insane roller coasters that you can create with all the endless amounts of combinatios of scenery of foliage to surround those roller coasters and rides and transform them into attractions. The only thing that is bad about the game is the guests AI. If they see something in the distance, like a massive to scale model of "Millenium Force" from Cedar Point, Ohio, and there is a square of path that doesn't connect to the path "Millenium Force" is on, they will just run around in circles and annoy you. But i can't complain that much because this game was created by only A SINGLE PERSON, Chris Sawyer. This man was an absolute wizard creating this game. Very Very great game. 9.8/10

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												I remember playing the first RCT many years ago, and loving it. I'd call it a timeless classic. This game is basically RCT 2.0, and that's a great thing indeed. Something I want to mention is that I'm playing on Windows 10, and have had absolutely no issues. Can even alt-tab without anything breaking.Gameplay;Fantastic. Addictive. Fun. Almost perfect for what it is. You really do have full control over how you build your park. Lots of customization and fine-tuning, with lots of selections for rides and shops. You oversee every aspect of your park, and making changes to any small detail is usually easy. The one complaint I have is how often visitors puke. It gets frustrating when you're trying to keep up your park rating.Level design/world/visuals;Not gonna lie, it can be a bit annoying trying to expand parks in scenarios. There's gonna be lots of rides and paths already in the park, and working around it can get frustrating. It's not terrible, though. Despite being released in a time when games came in cereal boxes, the visuals are honestly very good. They're pixelated, but full of detail. The animations are also good. Sound;Awesome. Quite a few tracks that can be selected for lots of different rides, all of which are good. The theme song/main menu music is by far the most memorable.Content;Virtually endless. It all depends on how much you enjoy the game, or how long you spend on one park. You can play one park/scenario for hours and be done, or replay every scenario multiple times. Or, make your own scenarios! Verdict;Couldn't be happier with this game. Definitely one of my favorites; one that I see myself playing on and off for quite a few years. As is the first installment, it's a classic. And, in my opinion, still the best after the release of the 3 big rollercoaster-park type games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Revisting the first game I've ever played has been a wonderful experience. It runs just as well on a Windows 7 machine as it does on an old XP (better, actually!). It's simple enough to be easily picked up and played with, but there's still challenging scenarios to play through and have fun with so that it's not too easy. Customization is pretty thorough - there are lots of scenery elements for many different types of aesthetic, plenty of rides (both prefabricated and custom-built track-types), lots of food vendors and trinket shops (balloons are popular!), and you can easily alter the landscape for underground building or filling in ponds and such. Word to the wise: Don't play it without picking up the patch that allows you to put it into windowed mode - it's way too annoying otherwise. If you're a fan of tycoon games, you really ought to pick this one up. I've heard things about the game not running on Windows 8 or 10, but I can't be for certain.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												PROS:-It's Rollercoaster Tycoon-It's pretty much the same as the first game except with more stuff, meaning they didn't ruin everything. The ATM and boatload of scenery is especially a nice touch-I've read it's considered the "best" Rollercoaster Tycoon, meaning there's likely a healthy supply of fanmade content for the gameCONS:-20 second long crowd noise loop still irritating as hell. "ROLLER COASTER" "BUT WHYYYYY" "EHAHAHAHAHA. BWAAAHH. OOOHOOOOHOOOHOOO." It was cute for nostalgic reasons for about 2 minutes before I wished they made a longer, more varied sound for crowded areas-It's pretty much the same as the first game except with more stuff, meaning they didn't seem to add that much-The scenarios suck my toes. Almost all of the ones I've tried so far make you wonder if they even put any thought into making them. Half the time the existing rides don't even have names. The scenery looks good (or, at least, it probably did back in the day, so I'm trying to judge it on that) but most of the time it just gets in the way. Sometimes guests get lost on the pre-existing paths. You rarely allowed to charge per ride so you're stuck entirely relying on vendors and admission fees. Give me Forest Frontiers or Dynamite Dunes over Alcatraz and Rio anyday-Maybe I haven't figured it out yet but it seems like there's no way to access the Steam community inside the game, which makes playing while you're chatting with someone a pain in the neck.Overall, despite my criticisms, it's cheap and fun and it's in no way worse than the original (aside from the scenarios). If you're asking yourself if you want to pick it up, you probably do.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												Hands down the best tycoon game out there. It has aged for sure, but still remains fun and challenging. I'd like to point out you can play the original scenarios from the first game as well -just google RCT 1 scenarios for RCT 2- which, in my opinion, are a lot more fun than the RCT2 ones. Would also like to give a shoutout to OpenRTC2. This project aims to "translate" RCT2 into another coding language (simply put) which would allow for actual mods etc. for it to be created. Google it as well- It's still in early development, but looks very promising.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Reminds me that even as a child I was messed up in the head.I actually worked out the statistics for crashes when the ride is red and when its green as a kid. If you really want people to die, make all your rides red. I don't know 100% if it does change anything but its worth a try.Try putting angry guests on a remote island on your map, then sink the ground in and put a info center down there. If you want to go the extra mile then re-name them all the bad guests: Autistic.Make a ride that launches into space, or crashes into another cart. Or one that throws them into other guests on the path.I did all this as a kid, and had a hell of a lot of fun. I can not recommend this enough to sick psychopaths like me.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 is one of those games you can't hate. Ok maybe you can hate it, but if you do, then you don't know what true fun is. Gameplay: 9/10The building in this game is fluid. The path system is very easy to use, and even has options for elevation. The rollercoaster building is a little sketchy at first but when you get used to it, then you can make some crazy stuff. Not only that the terrain tool is fantastic but with the only downside is no mountain tool like in RCT 1.Music: 10/10It's so catchy and will keep you reeled in. The music is so memorable that it will keep you humming it from days on end.Presentation: 9/10The game looks great. You can't really go wrong with 2d sprites. Everything from the peeps to the rides are so detailed that it makes your eyes bleed. But in all honesty the game looks fantastic with an overall point of "you don't need fancy 3d graphics to make a game look good".Overall score: 10/10There is seriously no reason as to why you shouldn't pick this game up. Weither it screams nostalgia from your childhood or even looks remotely awesome, then I would very HIGHLY reccomend this game. It will provide you with hours on end fun and amazing gameplay that you wouldn't wanna stop playing it.

												I used to love the 1st one. I don't know why, but the 2nd one despite being almost the same (but with more stuff) rubs me the wrong way. Maybe it's because I don't have the nostalgia feels to it.The game itself is like a big sandbox, with plenty of options to make your own distinct Luna Park. But the biggest downside for me is that you can't build rides with the time paused. And decorating can be very clumsy. And with micromanagment piling up it really frustrates me. I want to build the perfect track and not be bothered (yet) with mundane problems! This duality of building and managment wasn't as apparent to me in the 1st one, I think, because it lacked many decorations, so it was more straightforward.I must point the fact that the game is working with 16:9 aspect ratio, which is realy sweet.

Posted: June 7, 2015
												I recommend this version of the game; it seems to work quite well on windows 7 actually.Oh, and I recommend the game in general as well, of course. It's good, as others will be quick to tell you.Here are some things that are worth knowing:* Unlike my old copy of the game, saving actually DOES work in the steam version!* It is indeed an old game, and the interface may be a bit confusing if you're used to more modern fare.* The AI is incredibly dumb, which can be frustrating. Once you get used to it, it just adds a bit of challenge.* The parks can sometimes get a bit cluttered and visually confusing.* The game isn't gorgeous, but its pixel graphics do the job. The rollercoasters look great. Don't buy it for the graphics.* The game has some weird quirks, like odd sell values and not being able to build while paused.* The gameplay is still very good; designing parks is fun, designing rollercoasters is fun, there's plenty of stuff to do.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												The definitive version of RollerCoaster Tycoon.  It's not very different from the first game, but there are many small improvements here and there.  Fans have also recreated the first game's scenarios with the in-game scenario editor, so you won't be missing out.  A legendarily fun game, though having no unlockables this time is disappointing.This may not run well, or at all, if you have Windows 7 or 8.  Find the demo and see if it works on your computer.  It did on my version of Windows 7, so there is hope yet.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This review is coming from someone who purchased rct3 before purchasing rct2.  Those of you that own rct3 and are considering purchasing rct2, this review should help.  So I will list pros and cons about rct2 compared to rct3PRO'S: - The peeps (AI) form sizeable queue lines for your rides, making you feel like your ride is popular- Lag does not exist in this game- Created by Chris Sawyer- Altogether, it feels like a better game (in my opinion, of course)- Go Karts are overpowered :)- Pre-built Six Flags amusement parks - Awesome Pre-built rides (If you're lazy...)- Unique scenarios (i.e. Great Wall of China scenario where you have unlimited money but have to keep park rating above 700 at all times.)CON'S:- No 3D view like in RCT3- You can't ride your rollercoasters- Park staff are equally as useless as they are in RCT3- No nighttime phase (some would consider that a pro)CONCLUSION: Overall, there is not a significant difference between RCT 2 and 3.  Atari didn't change much for RCT3 other than 3D view.  If you thoroughly enjoyed RCT3, you will thoroughly enjoy this game.

Posted: August 24, 2015
												Well over a decade on, and there is not another single game I have ever played for likely even half of the time as I have RCT2.  And that includes some MMOs that have a year+ logged in time.  I nearly cried with happiness when I finally realized this was on Steam.  I bought RCT2 and the two expansions when they each launched, and the triple thrill pack - I used the TTP disc so much It was *taped together*.  I spent hours getting it to line up when it started to crack.  Thats a sign of how amazing this game is. If you find building and sim games fun, you can't go wrong here.  The customization and themes are awesome and can give hours of fun.You can also download all of the maps from the original RCT for this, a large chunk of which were released officially, and hundreds if not thousands of other maps custom designed.  There are some amazing parks out there.Fun tip, there is a .dll mod out there to run it in windowed mode.  For some reason its not default in RCT2, but it was an option in the original..

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This review is coming from someone who purchased rct3 before purchasing rct2.  Those of you that own rct3 and are considering purchasing rct2, this review should help.  So I will list pros and cons about rct2 compared to rct3PRO'S: - The peeps (AI) form sizeable queue lines for your rides, making you feel like your ride is popular- Lag does not exist in this game- Created by Chris Sawyer- Altogether, it feels like a better game (in my opinion, of course)- Go Karts are overpowered :)- Pre-built Six Flags amusement parks - Awesome Pre-built rides (If you're lazy...)- Unique scenarios (i.e. Great Wall of China scenario where you have unlimited money but have to keep park rating above 700 at all times.)CON'S:- No 3D view like in RCT3- You can't ride your rollercoasters- Park staff are equally as useless as they are in RCT3- No nighttime phase (some would consider that a pro)CONCLUSION: Overall, there is not a significant difference between RCT 2 and 3.  Atari didn't change much for RCT3 other than 3D view.  If you thoroughly enjoyed RCT3, you will thoroughly enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game brings back lots of childhood memories. All that time spent creating parks and in particular, tons of wild roller coasters. This game is still great even after all these years. I've played this for much longer than my Steam time shows. I've played 1, 2, and 3, and I have to say this and 1 are close in which is my favorite. The gameplay is simple yet fun, I'd recommend picking it up if you can, it's a great way to spend a couple of hours at a time trying to beat yet another scenario. There's lots of variety in parks and ride in here. Although honestly the two expansion packs didn't add much original stuff, just rethemed rides and lame scenarios that somewhat force you into a box regarding park design. You can also create your own scenarios or download ones that others have made. I'd also recommend adding the UCES expansion, a community expansion that added tons of scenery, a bunch of scenarios, and a few new rides. It might be a little hard to find now as the official site no longer exists, but there are alternate downloads around for it. Just a word of warning, the first time you run a UCES scenario, it will usually crash the game. This is normal as the first time you run the scenario any custom content used in it must be installed. The next time you select the scenario it should run just fine.If you want to make your own scenarios, you can also pick up some custom rides and themeing that are out there. Amazing Earl and Buggy are two people to look up. There is also a pack that contains almost all the scenarios from RCT1 and its expansions which have been remade for RCT2. Just google "RCT1 scenarios for RCT2" and that should get you something.Pros:+Great variety of rides available, including lots of roller coasters+Various scenario objectives and scenarios for lots of variety+Low system requirements will run on pretty much any computer+Lots of extra community content (if you know where to find it)+Fun way to spend a few hoursCons (These are mostly nitpicky):-Scenario editor is fairly limited, making a park that has pre-built rides is a bit round-a-bout and not the best way-Expansions don't offer much in terms of new rides, just a bunch of rethemeing-Scenario selection screen can get cluttered/hard to navigate if you have lots of scenarios installed-No career/progression. All scenarios are available from the start unlike 1 & 3.A final note, some people may have issues running this on newer machines. I have a 64 bit Windows system, and I have no problem running it at all. A demo can probably be found online, install that and run it before buying to check that it will work on your system.Overall 10/10, a classic that still stands the test of time.

Posted: July 5, 2015
												If there's one game out there that I spent more hours playing than Skyrim, S.T.A.L.K.E.R., Command & Conquer and even Pokemon combined, it would have to be this game. I started playing this back at my cousins house on their computer, addicted to creating new crazy rides and of course drowning unwanted patrons to my park. Of course that would only be as a last resort...Picking this game up again brought me back to that time when I really did enjoy this game, and still enjoy it. Even though the AI can be a bit dumb and don't know when to go to the restroom or First Aid desk if they're feeling sick. Or even when I hire on 30 mechanics and yet not one of them get to a certain ride that's my main attraction.But if you get past that, there's so much creativity that this game has potential for you'll enjoy it for hours, or even days on end. If you like playing games older simulation games like Sim City, you'll enjoy this one hands down. I highly recommend this to any of my friends or those wishing to play some good ol' nostalgia.

Posted: April 23
 General Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 is one of the most loved all-time favourite games. A must have game no matter how retro the graphics are. RCT2 is a single player game where you manage finances while building a theme park either from scratch or partly built. Roller Coaster Tycoon 2 is actually quite in-depth as the physics can change during a ride due to the weight (how many people are riding the coaster) which can increase or decrease the speed of which the train is going. Weather, hunger & ride intensity are also contributing factor to peeps happiness and some peeps will prefer certain types of rides. There are numerous scenarios to complete ranging from several difficulties, not including custom made scenarios. One of the wonders of this game is that it is moddable so you can add custom roller coaster designs or scenery. One major unofficial update to this game is OpenRCT which adds extra features, rides & scenery. It has now enabled multiplayer mode so you can build the theme park of your dreams with your mates. UI The UI couldn’t be simpler. The block style does look a little old and needs updating although this is what you get for a 2002 year old game. Finding information is very simple and can be found with a few clicks. Graphics The retro looking isometric style gives the game a great look and feel although can sometimes be hard when placing scenery in the correct position. The only downside is that some objects are not able to be placed on the same tile but this can be overcome with some trainer mods applied. I would recommend this game

Posted: June 19, 2015
												I picked this up because I spent way too much time playing RCT2 back in the day, but never got to play the expansions. Even though the base game has countless hours of potential, the expansions bring even more to the already expansive base.The best thing about this game is that even after almost two decades have passed, it still holds up as one of the best tycoon games, even surpassing most of the contemporary ones (especially the modern iterations of the RollerCoaster Tycoon series). You can even find ways to kill your guests if you're some kind of sadist or psycopath. In most circles, it's become one of the "staples" of PC gaming, standing up there with X-COM, Doom, and Half-Life.It's cheap, it ran great on old computers (and is guaranteed to run silky smooth on any machine from the last 5 years, even laptops), it's endless fun, frankly there's no reason not to get this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												The second game in the RollerCoaster Tycoon series adds stackable scenery, more types of said scenery, AND a pretty solid scenario creator. I personally played 1 a whole lot more, but I love most of the games in this series (RCT4 and RCT-3DS excluded).You manage your own theme park, right down to stalls and staff-wages. But the biggest draw is the ability to build your own RollerCoasters and other tracked-rides. You can either build the most basic ride that barely leaves the station, goes up a hill, and returns. Or you can build the most massive coaster you can afford, spanning the entire park from front to back , and left to right. There is a nice collection of pre-made scenarios that present you with a range of different challenges. Unfortunately, there is less variety in RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 scenarios than there were in the original. But it makes up for that with a highly-robust scenario creator that you can use to challenge your friends with your own devilish creations.If you like any of the rest of the series, this is a pretty solid addition to your library.

												I don't really know what to say about RCT2 except it's fun as hell.... content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												An old game, but one of my all time favourites. The gameplay still holds up today, but be warned that this is NOT an HD remaster/remake. That means you may run into minor issues when trying to run it on Windows 7/8. That being said, I was able to play it right out of the box with no real issues.EDIT: Installing the mod OpenRCT2 really resolves a lot of these issues, as well as adding many improvements. highly recommended. This would be a bit more relavent if the regular version of RCT2 was on Steam, but the extra expansion content that comes with the Triple Thrill Pack is really not well done. Still, well worth the $10 for a timeless classic.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This game is the best in the series. It has all of the features of the first game with additions and it is not streamlined like the 3rd game. You can build roller coasters, or simply buy preconstructed templates for roller coasters. Both are fun. The only problem is customer and worker AI. They will walk past food and drink stands even though they say they're starving/thirsty, get lost even though they have a map, and they treat transportation as rides, not as transportation in the park, meaning that if you have a train ride leading to an isolated part of the map, they will get stuck there and get angry and not use the train ride to go back. Handymen and Mechanics are absolute necessities, but their pathfinding is terrible. Even if you use guided pathways for mechanics, they will disobey you and inspect other rides. When you have 20+ rides, it is very hard to manage.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												If you dislike this game because of the graphics then you are playing it for the wrong reasons. This game has immense replay value because of the custom tracks, endless options for scenery, paths, and buildings.Having a built-in map editor is a perk as well, so you can play flat open areas to create your ultimate dream park with infinte money. Oh and also "I WANT TO GET OFF MR BONES WILD RIDE"Whether it is nostalgia or you are new to RCT this is a great game to play and you can sink in a lot of hours before you realize you've played 8 hours straight.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I dont have RCT1 on steam,  and RCT1 and 2 are largely the same game, so I'm writing this on behalf of both games.Loved them when I was a kid, While Half Life 2 and the Sims were what cemented my interest in PC gaming when I was young, if I had to pick one game that probably got me into it in the first place, it would be Rollercoaster Tycoon.  Saw my father playing it when I was a kid and was drawn in from the start.Even for it's dated isometric style, it's aged considerably well, and I still play the Modded OpenRCT2 on Multiplayer with friends today.Whether you're playing it for nostalgia, or taking the p*ss and just making deathtraps, It's always been a great game.

content:
Posted: January 6
												I remember LOVING this game as a kid. Unfortunately, like many new games it lacks proper support for windows 10. What you are buying is a broken and unstable game. After messing with the compatability settings you will get it to run however at the cost of being plaigued with game crashes and glitches. I had a wonderful park started and then the game glitched causing me to no longer have the ability to unlock new rides and food stands. When the game does unlock things for you it seems to be in a way that doesnt make sense both in the amount of time taken, as well as which rides you unlock. Long story short is that unless you are running this game on an old OS you probably should avoid it. But if you have old operating systems you will be enjoying the game immensely. Do I reccomend this game? No, most people have windows 8 or 10 at this point and I dont know that it will run much better on 7. If you have xp I highly recommend it!

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												It's a good game and this is a nice pack but there are some things you should be aware of. If changes have been made to the initial release then they're minimal and don't fix many issues you're likely to have. The biggest one is the resolution. There is no windowed mode so the picture always looks stretched and blurry on larger monitors. An unofficial patch can fix this. Another is a gameplay issue - big parks will always get low satisfaction ratings because stupid guests will walk deep into the park, want to go home but take forever to get out, dragging your ratings down. No entry signs are the best solution here but they're a workaround rather than a fix.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is one of my favorite sim games from my childhood, as for the game itself, i would give it 5 stars considering its age.  However, there does not appear to have been any updates/fixes before releasing this on steam.  I'm not expecting new graphics or content, but i'm expecting it to be playable without having to download 3rd party hacks.  In my experience, it has been a very buggy game since purchasing on steam, others may have better luck, take note of the fact that windows 7/8 are both not officially supported in the system requirements.Graphics issues abound, don't even think about ever using alt-tab while playing this game, it may still be playable, but frequently the colors will change to what seems like an 8-bit pallette? it is not a good look.  The game frequently takes several tries to start, the music almost always works, but the graphics frequently do not (black screen w/music).  There are numerous workarounds and third party hacks/launchers that help to minimize these issues, but it is a lot of extra work, and none of them quite 'fix' it.  Make sure to save often, the game has quit on me numerous times, frequently the cursor will stop working altogether, or you'll find yourself clicking on one area, but the game recognizing it as you clicking on another area, very frustrating.For the times when you do get to play the game, however, it's glorious.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 is a very fun game when you get into it. You might have a bit of a slow start with it (your attack and speed will be halved for five whole turns!), but soon, you'll be building parks that rival the best real world parks. Manage your finances wisely, though. If you go crazy, you might find yourself in debt. There's a great amount of content for this game, and though it probably won't last forever, it's definitely capable of taking a few hundred hours out of your slowly decreasing lifetime. At least those few hundred hours will be spent having fun.Please, try not to kill people. You can do that in this game, but please don't. It will be detrimental for your park's reputation, and also, it's killing people. I have yet to understand why so many players decide to kill their guests.Windows 10 users, you may experience a problem with the game. It tends to crash very frequently on Windows 10, but there's a way around it. If you go into the steam files for RCT2 and troubleshoot the program's compatabiliy, you should be able to set it to run in Windows 7 mode. If you do that, it should work fine.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												RCT 2 expands off the base game of RCT and does it in a fun and creative way. Creating buildings of any size and height was a much needed improvement and necessity although it took many hours to create a massive tower. RCT 2 had a fun circus feel to the game when interacting with the peeps and building roller coasters, Creating rides while enhancing the scenery to theme the ride was as much fun as building roller coasters was. Managing the park was basic and at times could get in the way of building an exciting park. Enhancing the mouse control were a much needed improvement and helped when building a larger park with many roller coasters. Adding the ability to create and add your own objects to the game brought the game play to a new level where gamers could actually get more out of the game by allowing more content options making it a better game overall.The peep interaction was fun, and created a more fun game experience. Having spent hundreds of hours in game play, this is one of those games that could never get boring unlike other simulation builders. The soundtrack to the game was fantastic and added to the pleasure of playing, often at times, wanting to get you to listen to the sound effects more than the music. The humorous feel to the game put the player in a happy mood ready to craft a park just to hear the peeps happy laughter. The interaction was captivating and provided a fun experience for each and every hour you put into the game. 5 stars out of 5 stars. A very time consuming game because of the fact it was just plain fun to play.

												RCT2 is strongly recommended for any simulation/management fans. This 2002 game shows that a good design and an eye for quality goes a long way. Posted: August 9, 2015
												Some call it an improvement upon the first game, others call it a step back.It's middle ground, it improves in many elements of gameplay, but in terms of how the first game felt like you were progressing to earn new parks to play in, RCT2 gives you every park right off the start. No longer do you need to work on the easier parks to progress upward, you can start easy, or you can start off hard as you like.The addition of additional resolutions in RCT2 was always welcomed, and since the release of OpenRCT, the community will be working on making the game as perfect as possible.

Posted: April 12, 2015
												If you've played the original RCT, than you'll love RCT2. Bear in mind, this game is more than a decade old now and running on an engine even older than that. I've been playing RCT since 1999, and I've been playing RCT2 since its come out. I literally have logged thousands of hours on this title, and its one of the few games I binge play.RCT2 brings a huge collection of roller coasters, rides, shops, and scenery items to the table. If this isn't enough, RCT2 will also support custom flat rides and scenery items; although the online community has flatlined over the years (there are still some good sites to pull content from). You can even skip the whole career/story mode and jump right into a sandbox!One of the reasons this game has survived for so long is because its extremely easy to play and it masterfully blends several things you like in a game... sandbox, simulation, and design. RCT2 is about as user friendly as it gets, with the learning curve set to child. You are literally limited by your own creativity. This is by far one of the most fluid, relaxing, and satisfying game to play.If only Atari would collaborate with Colossal Order, then we could have a game with the impeccable game design of RCT2 and the realism of Cities: Skylines. THAT would be the perfect way to revisit this dusty, old franchise and that would be a MONSTER hit since this whole genre of gaming pretty much ends at RCT2.

												RCT2 is arguably my favorite game of all time.  Build your own rides, make them do whatever you want, manage your park successfully.If you get bored, build some deathtraps for your guests.  Throw your angry guests into the ocean.This is probably the game I've spent the most time in my life playing.  Only recently added it to steam, but I've likely logged thousands of hours.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 is a very fun game when you get into it. You might have a bit of a slow start with it (your attack and speed will be halved for five whole turns!), but soon, you'll be building parks that rival the best real world parks. Manage your finances wisely, though. If you go crazy, you might find yourself in debt. There's a great amount of content for this game, and though it probably won't last forever, it's definitely capable of taking a few hundred hours out of your slowly decreasing lifetime. At least those few hundred hours will be spent having fun.Please, try not to kill people. You can do that in this game, but please don't. It will be detrimental for your park's reputation, and also, it's killing people. I have yet to understand why so many players decide to kill their guests.Windows 10 users, you may experience a problem with the game. It tends to crash very frequently on Windows 10, but there's a way around it. If you go into the steam files for RCT2 and troubleshoot the program's compatabiliy, you should be able to set it to run in Windows 7 mode. If you do that, it should work fine.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												Anyone having trouble with the game crashing I have reasreced for a few hours and stumbled upon Budget_player_cadet's solution which worked for me and most likely for you aswell "So I was getting random crashes with Windows 8, and I found what appears to be a workaround. First, go to library, and under launch options for RCT2, enter "-winxp". That sets it to windows XP compatibility mode. Next, go to your Games folder and you should find the RCT2 .exe file. Run it as an administrator. This seems to have solved the problem for me."

Posted: July 27, 2014
												I had this game on CD-rom when I was a kid, and it still works on my old computer, but now that it's on steam, I can play it much easier and have just as much fun as I did when I was younger.The point of the game is to create amusment parks and build rides to complete a specific goal, if you don't your park gets shut down. It's not something you think would be fun to play, but it is. You get to completely customize how your rides are built, you decide where people can walk, whether your guests live or drown in the nearest pool of water, you can even create a park designed to make your guests suffer an untimely demise. All that with the ability to create your own parks with their own objectives, there's plenty to keep you entertained.The game isn't perfect though, removing unneeded footpaths can be slightly annoying due to the isometric camera angle and somewhat picky programming, but it's nothing that makes the game even slightly less fun.If you haven't experienced this game yet, pick it up, you'll surely enjoy yourself. After all, what other game lets you build your own six flags parks, or build parks on volcanoes or prison islands?

Nostalgic.Works on Win 8.1, To fix the Error Trapper resolution/driver issue without tampering with the game go to Games in Steam > Right Click RTC2 > Properties > local files > browse local files > Right Click RTC2 > Properties > Compatibility.Run in Compatibility mode on Windows XP and you wont get the driver issue anymore.

Posted: May 17, 2015
												The kids of today have no idea what they're missing, the childhood retro game from the real days of gaming, playing this again just proves that consoles such as the XB1 / PS4 and companies trying to make games with the most realistic graphics are pointless.Hearing the background music on the menu and listening to all the sound effects of the game was like it had only been a blink of an eye since last playing, picked up everything straight away, and started to build my park.If you've never played this game before and wonder what all the fuss is about, it's simply the nostalgia effect, if 2015 or beyond is your first time playing this game then you might not get the enjoyment as much as those who did when this was first released.I must admit the game is probably best played in small doses as opposed to hours because it can become a bit repetitive and the same, there's stalls etc to unlock and rides but nothing in terms of leveling up, the game is designed to be the occasional very layed back trip down memory lane.Around £7-8 at time of writing this review, no brainer.

												Ignoring the bugs, which I managed to fix, this is a pretty solid title. Though it "sold out" to Six Flags, this has more content than the first game.Where it faltered was in the quality of this content. Many of the rides just seem like duplicates of each other, reskins with no real variation from the original designs. Also, some of the levels aren't very fun to play. They're either too tedious, too constricting, or too lazily designed.For sandbox theme park simulation, it's not as good as its predecessor, but it's still worth a few hours of time.

Posted: May 22, 2015
												Ahhhhh, the nostalgia. The first time i saw this game was while a friend was playing a demo of the first one. I was immediately caught. I was like 12 years old at the time, and i guess it was every boys' dream to be able to build an amusement park.If you ever dreamed about building an amusement park this is the game for you. The interactions of the game are really simple and the sound of the game is one of the things that will make you be hooked on it. Hearing screams from the rollercoasters, the old music of classic merry-go-rounds, it is just good. The graphics are good in a simplistic way, and i like that. Well, no one expected much better at the year that this game was released. There's not much to say, this game is an amusement park management game, that looks exactly like it does on the imagesGraphics 9/10 - Considering the actual release date the graphics are good and simple, just how i like itSound 10/10 - If you love the sound of classic amusement parks you'll be stuck with the sound of the game in your head for a whileGameplay 9/10 - Really simple, just click and drop.Personal Enjoyment 9/10 - I really like the game, but it gets hard at some point in some maps, and might make you kind of bored of the game

Posted: June 21, 2016
												Between RCT and RCT2, definitely go for RCT2, as it's really easy to simply add all the old scenarios back in, in addition to hundreds of custom scenarios the fans have made over the years. Unfortunately many of the RCT2 scenarios feel a bit off. Something I liked about the original and many of the custom scenarios is that they mostly felt like places you actually might build a theme park, like around a giant lake. With a couple exceptions the RCT2 scenarios mostly go for weirdness, like building a park on mars, or for stuff that doesn't feel quite realistic, like building a park around the great wall of china. I know that's quite a dumb complaint, and it obviously doesn't mean you shouldn't get the game, but I never could get into building a park that really felt quite right around the grand canyon. Since there are so many great ones available it doesn't really matter.However RCT2 is an excellently designed sequel in that in almost all ways it is a direct upgrade over the previous game (and it's much better than its successor RCT3 in a lot of ways too.) There are more rides, better decorations, among lots of other improvements. This game is a classic through and through and at the heart of things its just really fun to make an amusement park, and you really owe it to yourself to try it if you haven't already.

Posted: August 19, 2016
												This was one of my childhood favorites. I remember when I had my old PC and had this and all of the expansion packs on it. It was just so much fun!FEATURES:- You can create roller coasters (duh).- You can hire staff to entertain your visitors/clean up your park/fix your rides.- You can rename individal people and staff to deliver torture to your worst enemy!- You can build at such places as Alcatraz Prison and the Great Wall of China!- You can also create food stands, souvenier shops, etc.- You can be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and charge people to use the only toilet in your park.There are some downsides to this game however. For example:- It will crash every now and again, but that's just because the game is old.- The isometric view may screw you up a bit when it comes to building your coasters.- Other bugs that I may have forgotten to mention.This game for me only got better when I discovered OpenRCT2, a mod that enhances the game. BIG time.Here's the link:https://openrct2.org/I definitely reccommend getting OpenRCT2 if you truly want to expand your experience with this game.OpenRCT2 Features:- Can make rides go faster than 500 mph! (Caution: this may crash the game if used excessively in one park)- Can change the carts of every ride to something else (I.E: Replacing the regular roller coaster carts with a tram)- Fixes (most) bugs from the original game.- Adds in cheats so you can manipulate your customers/park to your very whim!- Adds in MULTIPLAYER!! That's right, MULTIPLAYER!! (I haven't tried it for myself yet, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that is impressive to convert a game like this into a multiplayer experience)- Fixes (most) crashes, unless you cause the crashes yourself.Do I reccommend this game by itself? Yes.Do I reccommend this game with OpenRCT2? The definitive choice.10/10 for me.As a bonus, here's some tips for both the standalone game and OpenRCT2 (based on the "Build Your Own Six Flags Park" Scenario):- Start slow. Don't go right into building coasters. Build food stands and simple rides (Ghost House, for example) until you have enough people in your park. Otherwise, you will have blown all of your money and spent at least $20,000 of your $100,000 loan.- Go easy on the inversions for most rides. You can have a big coaster with a lot of inversions, but don't do it for every ride. Not only does it become confusing after a while, but your guests won't like it.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) You can go fast, but don't go TOO fast. 200 mph should be fine, but don't do a 50 lap coaster going at 500 mph. This will probably crash the game.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) Turn on the cheat "Unlock all prices". That way, if you feel you're struggling with finances, you can charge people to go on your coasters. You'll thank me later.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) In multiplayer, don't be that guy that destroys one's park for the hell of it. If you want to get the most fun out of multiplayer, cooperate and come up with unique ideas for rides together.The reason why it says I only have roughly 1.3 hours is because playing OpenRCT2 doesn't show that you're playing RCT2 on Steam. OpenRCT2 is its own executable file that relies on the RCT2 binaries/files.Also, be sure to name your 3D Cinemas "The Legend of Harambe" and set the theme to "Storm Chasers". You'll thank me later.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												First off, the people who are giving this negative reviews for it crashing are complete jackasses. It's not the GAME'S fault whatsoever, it's the problem with newer OS's.Now that that's out of the way, this game is very fun. There's a lot to do and you have to think strategically and listen to what the people at your park want, don't want, or what they like and don't like or what they complain about. This makes it very challenging to make decisions on what you should add or take away, which also plays into the complicated financial part of the game. Also, with tools like "OpenRct2" this game has a bit of a "cult following" community (or amongst people like me who have seen people play the game on youtube with some humor), which does it a favor because people care about this game still by adding mods and multiplayer and new ideas to it. It's quite a magnificient feat that when a game that's almost two decades old and totally obsolete can have a following still and a community, and it's because it's a good game as well.

Posted: July 26, 2016
												Not many older games (pre-2005) that I've played seemed captivating enough to go back to and play more. But the Rollercoaster Tycoon series is an exception (except for RCT4 and RCT World, those dont count), specifically 1 and 2. Rollercoaster Tycoon 1 and 2 are very similar. In fact, they have pretty much the exact same graphics and the only thing that differentiates the two is the added rides/scenery/other content that RCT2 has over RCT1. The first two RCT games are timeless. If you play the game once and enjoy it, I can almost guarantee that you will enjoy it the next time you play. There are some people that don't enjoy it, (some of my friends IRL, for example) but usually that is because of judgement based on graphics/age or just a dislike of the management genre. If lacking high-quality graphics or being in the management genre are turn-offs for you, I'd still recommend playing this game at least once in your lifetime. Many people actually consider it a crime to NOT play this game at least once. To be perfectly honest, my best gaming memories come from two games: Pokemon Crystal and Rollercoater Tycoon 1. Whether you are dusting this game off after a long time without playing, or if you've never played this game before, it is a genuinely great game that should be in everybody's Steam library.

												Excluding Civ 2, the RCT series was possibly my favourite game from my mid/late teenage years.While the graphics and UI are, by today's standards, outdated, this is still an absolutely incredible game that any simulation fan/theme park fan should pick up.It's not the easiest on new players - it's pretty difficult to work out how to build coasters that don't terrify your peeps, and managing your staff to stop the park being destroyed is, at first, a HR nightmare, but once you get the hang of it, it's brilliant fun.Definitely recommended.

Posted: April 22, 2016
												An absolute classic for all gamers interested in Roller Coaster Management games. This game not only provides players with the ability to create a vast range of coasters, flat and dark rides, but also allows your imagination to shine. A huge range of decoration and scenery items, allows you to create a park of your dreams. This game combines the ability to create wonderful turns and twists of roller coasters, whilst having to manage the park from a staff point of view. Pricing of rides and merchandise, to taking out a loan to fund your new development area. This game has it all. If you manage to complete the huge varied range of levels, all of which focus on different themes and objectives, you can create your own scenarios for others to play, or, design rides to import into your park.I would highly recommend this game to anyone who has the most remote interest in theme parks!

												IF YOU HAVE WINDOWS 8.1 AND THIS GAME DOES NOT WORK FOR YOU, FOLLOW THESE STEPS!1. Scroll to the top right and select search2. In the search bar enter "Run programs"3. Select "Run programs made for previous versions of windows"4. Select "Next" it will then be starting to detect issues.5. It will give you a list of programs. Select "Rollercoaster Tycoon 2 Triple Thrill Pack" it will begin to detect issues with the program6. Select "Troubleshoot Program"7. It will give you a list of boxes. Select "The program worked in earlier versions of windows." Then select "Next."8. It will give you a list of previous versions of windows. Select "Windows XP service pack 2." Then select "Next."9. Test the program. DO NOT CONTINUE PLAYING. Exit the program if it does work which it should.10. After you exit select "Next."11. Select "Yes, save these changes."12. Select "Close Troubleshooter."13. Your game should work now. Enjoy!Also this game was my childhood. It is seriously great.

Posted: November 15, 2016
												Never ending fun.There is literally no end to this game, even after 14 years it still hold up, and has more replayability than any other game I've ever expirenced. In 3rd grade, I traded some Pokemon cards for the cereal box CD of this game, and it pretty much defined my childhood. But this is in no way just a nostalgia trip, although I do feel like a kid again when I play this. Even if you were not one of the lucky few who grew up on this masterpiece(what other game can handle 6k NPCs and not lag?), I promise you will find enjoyment here. Love detail? Let's sink 5 hours into making the perfect entry way and decorated que. Feeling bad? Launch a car load of people into space, or charge $20 for food and bathrooms on a prison island. Or just Love theme parks? Guess what, here you can make your own, however detailed or physics-defying(wait until you build scenery where the ride supports should be) you want. Even if you don't love theme parks, there is fun to be had in every nook and crany of this game, from the pre set scenarios to the scenario editor to the coaster creator.Of course, I have to mention the awesome software of and commuity at OpenRCT2. The mod enhances the game, introduces multiplayer, and lets this gem run on any PC and OS. Even a toaster could handle this. Prepare to never be able to forget the same 2 scream tracks, and build that music-making merry-go-round right at the entrace, you won't regret it. 9.5/10 The "ride must be a continuous circuit" message should die with Jenny S. when it falls off the screen. Just let me launch the looping coaster into a volcano.

												I have been playing this game off and on for about 11 years now. Even though this game got a lot of flak at launch for being much the same as the original game, I believe this title added a lot of extra elements that made the challenge mode experience more difficult and fun. It's a shame they made deathcoasters harder to make, but the added challenges and level editor had always drawn me to play this game instead of the original for so long. Buy this game on sale if you're not willing to put a lot of time into it though, there is no fast forward button and it requires you to idle for extended periods of time. Overall, a great game!

												For me, I love tycoon games, and when I got RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 for the 4th Of July, I was stoked! I had been wondering for a long time what this game would be like, and if would meet my expectations that I had for it. And I am happy to say I enjoyed it alot! For starters, it has a very simple interface, which makes it very easy to navigate through the menus. Also, the rollercoaster building tool is very easy to use. Also, the textures look so realistic, which allows the player to immerse the feeling that he/she is there. And of course, there is the scenario editor, which allow you to make your own scenarios for you to play in and complete. This is a very amazing game and is definitly worth the $9.99.
