Posted: August 19, 2016
												This was one of my childhood favorites. I remember when I had my old PC and had this and all of the expansion packs on it. It was just so much fun!FEATURES:- You can create roller coasters (duh).- You can hire staff to entertain your visitors/clean up your park/fix your rides.- You can rename individal people and staff to deliver torture to your worst enemy!- You can build at such places as Alcatraz Prison and the Great Wall of China!- You can also create food stands, souvenier shops, etc.- You can be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and charge people to use the only toilet in your park.There are some downsides to this game however. For example:- It will crash every now and again, but that's just because the game is old.- The isometric view may screw you up a bit when it comes to building your coasters.- Other bugs that I may have forgotten to mention.This game for me only got better when I discovered OpenRCT2, a mod that enhances the game. BIG time.Here's the link:https://openrct2.org/I definitely reccommend getting OpenRCT2 if you truly want to expand your experience with this game.OpenRCT2 Features:- Can make rides go faster than 500 mph! (Caution: this may crash the game if used excessively in one park)- Can change the carts of every ride to something else (I.E: Replacing the regular roller coaster carts with a tram)- Fixes (most) bugs from the original game.- Adds in cheats so you can manipulate your customers/park to your very whim!- Adds in MULTIPLAYER!! That's right, MULTIPLAYER!! (I haven't tried it for myself yet, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that is impressive to convert a game like this into a multiplayer experience)- Fixes (most) crashes, unless you cause the crashes yourself.Do I reccommend this game by itself? Yes.Do I reccommend this game with OpenRCT2? The definitive choice.10/10 for me.As a bonus, here's some tips for both the standalone game and OpenRCT2 (based on the "Build Your Own Six Flags Park" Scenario):- Start slow. Don't go right into building coasters. Build food stands and simple rides (Ghost House, for example) until you have enough people in your park. Otherwise, you will have blown all of your money and spent at least $20,000 of your $100,000 loan.- Go easy on the inversions for most rides. You can have a big coaster with a lot of inversions, but don't do it for every ride. Not only does it become confusing after a while, but your guests won't like it.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) You can go fast, but don't go TOO fast. 200 mph should be fine, but don't do a 50 lap coaster going at 500 mph. This will probably crash the game.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) Turn on the cheat "Unlock all prices". That way, if you feel you're struggling with finances, you can charge people to go on your coasters. You'll thank me later.- (OPENRCT2 ONLY) In multiplayer, don't be that guy that destroys one's park for the hell of it. If you want to get the most fun out of multiplayer, cooperate and come up with unique ideas for rides together.The reason why it says I only have roughly 1.3 hours is because playing OpenRCT2 doesn't show that you're playing RCT2 on Steam. OpenRCT2 is its own executable file that relies on the RCT2 binaries/files.Also, be sure to name your 3D Cinemas "The Legend of Harambe" and set the theme to "Storm Chasers". You'll thank me later.

Posted: June 6, 2015
												This is the quintessential time consumer simulation game. I'd say it plays just as well as I remember, but I've been playing it every since the day the first game was released. It takes everything the first game had, polishes every aspect of it, and throws a ton of new content in that never gets old. The unique visual style has barely aged a day, and the music will burrow its way right back into your brain. And that's just the base game.Possibly the best reason for buying this game digitally was the advent of OpenRCT2, a massive project that overhauls the game from the ground up, reworking it from assembly code to an increasingly easy to modify open-source software. It's created a limitless world for game modifications, from new maps and scenarios, new scenery, new ride and vehicle types, and tons of UI and technical improvements. There are even lovingly recreated versions of the scenarios from the first game - essentially giving you 1 and 2 for the price of just this game. Most importantly. the game can now run at 60 FPS at a 4k resolution; even 1080 was impossible for the base game, making playing on any setup incredibly simple. It even removes all compatibility issues with newer operation systems.RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 is a game that can only stand to get better and better with age.

Posted: November 15, 2016
												Never ending fun.There is literally no end to this game, even after 14 years it still hold up, and has more replayability than any other game I've ever expirenced. In 3rd grade, I traded some Pokemon cards for the cereal box CD of this game, and it pretty much defined my childhood. But this is in no way just a nostalgia trip, although I do feel like a kid again when I play this. Even if you were not one of the lucky few who grew up on this masterpiece(what other game can handle 6k NPCs and not lag?), I promise you will find enjoyment here. Love detail? Let's sink 5 hours into making the perfect entry way and decorated que. Feeling bad? Launch a car load of people into space, or charge $20 for food and bathrooms on a prison island. Or just Love theme parks? Guess what, here you can make your own, however detailed or physics-defying(wait until you build scenery where the ride supports should be) you want. Even if you don't love theme parks, there is fun to be had in every nook and crany of this game, from the pre set scenarios to the scenario editor to the coaster creator.Of course, I have to mention the awesome software of and commuity at OpenRCT2. The mod enhances the game, introduces multiplayer, and lets this gem run on any PC and OS. Even a toaster could handle this. Prepare to never be able to forget the same 2 scream tracks, and build that music-making merry-go-round right at the entrace, you won't regret it. 9.5/10 The "ride must be a continuous circuit" message should die with Jenny S. when it falls off the screen. Just let me launch the looping coaster into a volcano.

Posted: April 25, 2016
												IF YOU HAVE WINDOWS 8.1 AND THIS GAME DOES NOT WORK FOR YOU, FOLLOW THESE STEPS!1. Scroll to the top right and select search2. In the search bar enter "Run programs"3. Select "Run programs made for previous versions of windows"4. Select "Next" it will then be starting to detect issues.5. It will give you a list of programs. Select "Rollercoaster Tycoon 2 Triple Thrill Pack" it will begin to detect issues with the program6. Select "Troubleshoot Program"7. It will give you a list of boxes. Select "The program worked in earlier versions of windows." Then select "Next."8. It will give you a list of previous versions of windows. Select "Windows XP service pack 2." Then select "Next."9. Test the program. DO NOT CONTINUE PLAYING. Exit the program if it does work which it should.10. After you exit select "Next."11. Select "Yes, save these changes."12. Select "Close Troubleshooter."13. Your game should work now. Enjoy!Also this game was my childhood. It is seriously great.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												An amazing game for anyone interested in business sims, building sims, or just messing around in a theme park environment. The entire game is a blast, but some of my favorite game elements are: 1) designing awesome rollercoasters and other rides like go karts and water rides; 2) getting feedback from visitors and being able to use it to improve your park, 3) the general chatter and noise the people make is endearing, and 4) watching someone exit a ride that they love, and jumping in the air in excitement.I don't have a problem with (well done) games where you are basically just shifting around resources and reviewing spreadsheets, but this goes beyond that type of game, with a great balance between building, financial matters, employee guidance, visitor interactivity, and other matters.There's no major flaws IMO, but certain things might not be everyone's cup of tea. First, it can be a slow and leisurely game to play; Second, while it doesn't require a ton of micromanagement, nonetheless if you aren't willing to do at least *some* in-depth stuff (esp. with your workers) your park can become a mess; Third, the graphics and art are not bright and shiny and cartoonish in the way that a lot of business sims are (though for someone like me, this is a positive rather than a negative); Fourth, it's not in 3d, but like a 2.5d where you can look at things from 4 perspectives, and this can make seeing certain things difficult at times.Anyway, to sum up... if you are at all interested in this genre or theme, it'll almost certainly be worth it to get this. Go!

												First off, the people who are giving this negative reviews for it crashing are complete jackasses. It's not the GAME'S fault whatsoever, it's the problem with newer OS's.Now that that's out of the way, this game is very fun. There's a lot to do and you have to think strategically and listen to what the people at your park want, don't want, or what they like and don't like or what they complain about. This makes it very challenging to make decisions on what you should add or take away, which also plays into the complicated financial part of the game. Also, with tools like "OpenRct2" this game has a bit of a "cult following" community (or amongst people like me who have seen people play the game on youtube with some humor), which does it a favor because people care about this game still by adding mods and multiplayer and new ideas to it. It's quite a magnificient feat that when a game that's almost two decades old and totally obsolete can have a following still and a community, and it's because it's a good game as well.

Posted: November 5, 2015
												RCT 2 expands off the base game of RCT and does it in a fun and creative way. Creating buildings of any size and height was a much needed improvement and necessity although it took many hours to create a massive tower. RCT 2 had a fun circus feel to the game when interacting with the peeps and building roller coasters, Creating rides while enhancing the scenery to theme the ride was as much fun as building roller coasters was. Managing the park was basic and at times could get in the way of building an exciting park. Enhancing the mouse control were a much needed improvement and helped when building a larger park with many roller coasters. Adding the ability to create and add your own objects to the game brought the game play to a new level where gamers could actually get more out of the game by allowing more content options making it a better game overall.The peep interaction was fun, and created a more fun game experience. Having spent hundreds of hours in game play, this is one of those games that could never get boring unlike other simulation builders. The soundtrack to the game was fantastic and added to the pleasure of playing, often at times, wanting to get you to listen to the sound effects more than the music. The humorous feel to the game put the player in a happy mood ready to craft a park just to hear the peeps happy laughter. The interaction was captivating and provided a fun experience for each and every hour you put into the game. 5 stars out of 5 stars. A very time consuming game because of the fact it was just plain fun to play.

												Ahhhhh, the nostalgia. The first time i saw this game was while a friend was playing a demo of the first one. I was immediately caught. Posted: June 21, 2016
												Between RCT and RCT2, definitely go for RCT2, as it's really easy to simply add all the old scenarios back in, in addition to hundreds of custom scenarios the fans have made over the years. Unfortunately many of the RCT2 scenarios feel a bit off. Something I liked about the original and many of the custom scenarios is that they mostly felt like places you actually might build a theme park, like around a giant lake. With a couple exceptions the RCT2 scenarios mostly go for weirdness, like building a park on mars, or for stuff that doesn't feel quite realistic, like building a park around the great wall of china. I know that's quite a dumb complaint, and it obviously doesn't mean you shouldn't get the game, but I never could get into building a park that really felt quite right around the grand canyon. Since there are so many great ones available it doesn't really matter.However RCT2 is an excellently designed sequel in that in almost all ways it is a direct upgrade over the previous game (and it's much better than its successor RCT3 in a lot of ways too.) There are more rides, better decorations, among lots of other improvements. This game is a classic through and through and at the heart of things its just really fun to make an amusement park, and you really owe it to yourself to try it if you haven't already.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												An amazing game for anyone interested in business sims, building sims, or just messing around in a theme park environment. The entire game is a blast, but some of my favorite game elements are: 1) designing awesome rollercoasters and other rides like go karts and water rides; 2) getting feedback from visitors and being able to use it to improve your park, 3) the general chatter and noise the people make is endearing, and 4) watching someone exit a ride that they love, and jumping in the air in excitement.I don't have a problem with (well done) games where you are basically just shifting around resources and reviewing spreadsheets, but this goes beyond that type of game, with a great balance between building, financial matters, employee guidance, visitor interactivity, and other matters.There's no major flaws IMO, but certain things might not be everyone's cup of tea. First, it can be a slow and leisurely game to play; Second, while it doesn't require a ton of micromanagement, nonetheless if you aren't willing to do at least *some* in-depth stuff (esp. with your workers) your park can become a mess; Third, the graphics and art are not bright and shiny and cartoonish in the way that a lot of business sims are (though for someone like me, this is a positive rather than a negative); Fourth, it's not in 3d, but like a 2.5d where you can look at things from 4 perspectives, and this can make seeing certain things difficult at times.Anyway, to sum up... if you are at all interested in this genre or theme, it'll almost certainly be worth it to get this. Go!

Posted: November 27, 2016
												RCT has risen and fallen, and while it would seem that its mantle has been faithfully picked up by Planet Coaster, RCT2 will always hold a special place in my heart. The original RCT may as well have invented the "Tycoon" genre. Yes, there were competitors and RCT was not the first simulation game, but there's a reason no one remembers its competitors and why it seemed like after RCT every simulation game for the next 5 years had Tycoon in the title.The original RCT gave creative freedom to build whatever your imagination desired along with a set of increasingly challenging scenarios to test your strategy and management skills. RCT 2 perfected this formula. More coasters, more themes, more track options, more modes, more everything. Plus you could play with actual Six Flags and they finally added a straight sandbox.My gaming childhood was built on Smash Bros. and Rollercoaster Tycoon. RCT is the game that started it all. This is the only game in the series that's better in every way.

Posted: February 25
												Wow. This is the worst game release on steam I've ever seen. It crashes instantly when I try and launch it and the original installer is even included. What were they thinking?No, throw away the provided executable and use OpenRCT2 instead. That works flawlessly.Yet, at the same time, this is an excellent game. This is really nothing more than version 2.0 of the original Roller Coaster Tycoon. Same great game, but with some new features. This game could just as easily have been an expansion pack.Building attractions is always fun and there are plenty of scenarios to try. But it does kinda samey rather quickly. Seen one scenario, seen them all. Built one roller coaster, built them all. It is unquestionably still fun, but it gets repetitive rather quickly. This is a game you can fire up for a few hours when you are bored and need a little hobby project to work on for a while.One thing I noticed with the scenarios compared to the original is the overuse of decorative objects. You can easily get several thousand bucks just from removing the unmanageble messes that the scenarios come with. The issue isn't just the overuse, it's the type of unmanageable structures built for you. It is pretty much always hollow shells that are a pain to work with. Trying to edit them or put tracks/roads into them is an exercise in futility. They are built to look nice, not to be worked with.One thing I noticed is that it rarely matters what you build. Just build one of everything and guests will be happy. Maybe it gets more challenging with harder scenarios, but I doubt it. Ultimately the guests are very simple state machines that don't care about your attractions beyond the three key statistics for each one. It works, but it doesn't give a lot of depth.But overall? This is a great game. It's easy to forget the systems it runs on and just have fun working on a little pet project for a few hours.

Posted: January 20
												So if you are here then you most likely played this game when is came out many a year ago. So to answer your questions here you go..."Did it age well?" - Yes. While blowing 2D sprites up to a 2K monitor does show every pixle, the "campiness" of the look keeps it fresh. The gameplay is still intuitive, and you are still given quite a creative sandbox. Combined with custom ride tracks, there is still plenty of originality in this one."Replayable or just Nostaliga?" - A little of both. While there is still ginuine original fun in making new rides and parks, the amount of rides seems smaller than I remeber and the isometric graphics can wear on you. Eventually, the game seems small and runs its course."Worth $10?" - If you enjoyed it as a kid, then yes. Relive your days and spend $10 to kill a couple weekends."Addiction 2.0?" - No. So as a kid, I remeber playing for months and months and having dozens of custom tracks for every roller coaster. For this one, I played several weekends, let my girlfriend play a weekend, enjoyed the game, and put it back on the shelf. It won't suck you back in."Overall?" - If you are looking for an "I'm in between games right now" Game or are just wanting to relive some childhood memories, then you will enjoy money well spent on this.

Posted: March 6
												The best feeling is setting the price for umbrellas to at least $20, and then it rains ... and everyone suddenly wants to fork over their money. xD I also am obsessed with popping every stray balloon. All ducks must be forced to quack. Scenario Editor is the best thing for making a simple, relaxing level for your building itch. Guests can handle pathways more than a single square wide. The game doesn't beep every time a guest gets lost. Scenery options are adorable. Building a coaster isn't too difficult. The variety in food stalls tickle my fancy. The game itself runs beautifully on my laptop, although there is a weird occasional glitch where the window you use to load ans save games gets blacked out, and you have to "guess-click" to find your file. It's not a difficult thing to do, though. Do you like the first classic game? Want a version where you get to basically do whatever the nut sack you want? Here you go. This is it.
